Did you know the Sunrise Theatre might soon have a new operator?

The City of Fort Pierce has officially received five proposals from outside groups interested in taking over operations of the beloved downtown venue. Right now, the city runs the theaterâ€”but officials are hoping a management company can bring long-term stability.

During and after the pandemic, it reportedly lost more than $1 million a year, with the city and federal grants stepping in to keep it afloat. item.description: Lindsay School of the Arts puts on a beautiful production of a play titled, "On My Own" right in the heart of Fort Pierce!
item.dc:creator: Sunland News
item.content:encoded:
A Local Stage, A Big Story

So I want to tell you about this show I saw last weekâ€”but also the school behind it.

Letâ€™s talk about Lindsay School of the Arts. I first heard of LSA a couple years ago when my friend Kay invited me to an art showcase there. It was simple, but specialâ€”artwork from students lining the walls, families walking the halls, and an energy that just made you pause. Ever since, Iâ€™ve kept my eye on what theyâ€™re doing.

Fast forward to this monthâ€”I was at Cool Beans Brew, my favorite coffee shop in Fort Pierce (hands down), and I kept seeing these posters for a student-led show called â€œOn My Own.â€ Turns out, the team at Lindsay had been working on this musical since last summer, and everythingâ€”from the story, to the choreography, to the musicâ€”was created by the students themselves.

That alone is impressive. But what really struck me was the space.

LSA recently moved from their cozy Orange Ave location (yes, the one with the peacocks crossing the road) to a bigger building on Avenue A, where theyâ€™ve built out a full black box theater and designed a real arts campus from the ground up.

ğŸ’¬Â Why It Matters: These kids arenâ€™t just learning about artâ€”theyâ€™re creating it, producing it, and putting it on stage. The show was emotional, intense, and reflective of what young people are really thinking about today. Itâ€™s hard to put into words, but the message from the show has stuck with me (no spoilers incase they put it on again).

ğŸŸï¸ If you ever see an event, showcase, or open mic hosted by LSAâ€”go.ğŸ“And shoutout to Cool Beans for always being a creative hub in the heart of Fort Pierce.

This is the kind of local magic worth supporting.

ğŸ‹ğŸ‹Â The Main Squeeze
Fort Pierce to End Free Beach Parking by Yearâ€™s End

This might be your last summer of free parking at Jetty Park.

Fort Pierce is moving forward with a plan to install paid parking at Jetty Park, Jaycee Park, and South Causeway Park before the end of the year. The city says it spends around $300K annually maintaining these spots, and parking fees would help cover beach upkeep, safety, and infrastructure.

ğŸ’¬Â Why It Matters: Hereâ€™s where things get tricky. While the official line is that the money will go toward maintenance, some folks inside City Hall are concerned that those funds wonâ€™t actually go back into the parksâ€”or the Jetty area at all. Instead, thereâ€™s talk it could end up in the general fund, where itâ€™s harder to track and could get used for totally unrelated projects.

Plus, thereâ€™s still the big question:

Should locals have to pay? Some say absolutely notâ€”residents already support the city through taxes. Others argue a yearly pass is fair, as long as the money actually goes back to the beaches.

ğŸ‘€Â What We Know So Far:

  • Rates may be $3/hr, $20/day, or $60/year

  • The city is finalizing a contract with a private vendor

  • The commission is expected to vote next month

  • Other beach sites arenâ€™t included (for now)

ğŸ—£ï¸ Over to you: Do you think locals should be exempt? Should the money go directly back into the beach area? Why do you think this is really happening?

Leave your thoughts here.

Vero Beach met with Sen. Jay Collins about getting more time to file its overdue auditâ€”and maybe avoid losing $258K in state funds. They say itâ€™ll be done by April 30, but after months of financial mismanagement, a lot of folks arenâ€™t buying it.

ğŸ‘‰ Catch Up Here

The cityâ€™s looking to add two roundabouts on Paar Drive, but some residents say theyâ€™d rather have traffic lights. Crashes are up in the area, but locals arenâ€™t convinced roundabouts are the fix.

ğŸ‘‰ See the Debate

Cleveland Clinic North in Stuart shut down its labor & delivery unit this week. Now, moms may have to drive 20+ miles to Tradition to give birth. A nonprofit hopes to open a local maternity centerâ€”but itâ€™s still in early talks.

A Surf Park Rises on Midway Road ğŸ’¸

I heard a phrase once: â€œIf you live long enough, you live twice.â€ That feels true for this one.

If youâ€™ve been around since 2020, you probably remember whispers of a surf park coming to Fort Pierce. It sounded big, maybe too big. But nowâ€”out past the cattle fields on Midway Roadâ€”it looks like itâ€™s really happening.

ğŸ„ğŸ» Catch Up Quick: Koa Bay, a nearly $600 million surf park community, is officially underway. Set across 204 acres, the project promises 450 waves an hour, 1,100 homes, hotels, shops, yoga studios, co-working spaces, and even the worldâ€™s first floating surf pool.

Developers say the surf lagoon will offer real waves up to 7 feet tall, with zones for beginners and experienced surfers. The site is still largely hidden by tree coverage, but officials confirm that ground has been broken.

The project was approved by Fort Pierce commissioners in 2022. Itâ€™s expected to bring jobs, tourism, and new housing to the area.

ğŸ’° The Cost: Sessions are expected to cost $80, with residential memberships starting at $11,250 plus a $45,000 initiation fee.

Construction is ongoing, with residential phases expected to wrap by the end of 2026.

A man was killed Thursday night after being hit by a Brightline train in downtown Fort Pierce, near Avenue A and Depot Drive. Police say the train was headed north, sounded multiple horns, and still made impact. His name has not yet been released.

ğŸ‹Â The Main Squeeze: $103K and Counting? Fort Pierce Still Paying for Empty INC Building

Hereâ€™s a story that had me going: wait, what?

Back in 2021, the City of Fort Pierce leased the historic Means Court building to a nonprofit called Incubate Neighborhood Center (INC) for $12 a year. The goal? To turn the space into an incubation hub for local businesses, complete with entrepreneurship training, a kitchen incubator, and moreâ€”right in the heart of Lincoln Park.

But today, that building is still closed. And now, a Hometown News investigation reveals Fort Pierce taxpayers have footed over $100,000 in expensesâ€”utilities, mowing, fire monitoringâ€”even though the lease clearly says those costs were supposed to be paid by INC.

The building? Still not open. Itâ€™s actually been labeled â€œunlawfulâ€ for occupancy since February 2023. And even while closed, utility bills paid by the city reportedly ranged from $1,300 to $1,800 a month.Â ğŸ¤¯

INCâ€™s CEO Canieria Gardner says the city told her theyâ€™d handle the utilities â€œdespite the lease,â€ but no one from the city has confirmed who authorized it. Meanwhile, the nonprofit is leasing the $1 million property for $12 a year, with a written promise to take on all financial responsibility.

ğŸ’¬Â Why It Matters: This one raises more questions than answers. From lease terms to funding promises, it spotlights deeper concerns around transparency and oversightâ€”especially for a building many hoped would serve as a cornerstone of community and economic growth.

ğŸ‘‰ Read the full investigation by Hometown Newsâ€”itâ€™s worth your time.

  • City leaders see an opportunity to expand the museumâ€™s footprint by purchasing an adjacent property, ensuring the surrounding area reflects the investment made in the museum itself.

ğŸ’¬Â The Discussion:

Board members, including Commissioner James Taylor, suggested tapping into $2 million in available county tourism funds to cover outstanding change-orders and explore property acquisition. However, the city is still waiting on formal guidance from the countyâ€™s tourism director.

TL;DR: The Slate Rocks 5K took place on March 15, and I finally get to write about it. This wasnâ€™t just any raceâ€”it was a community-driven event in honor of my late uncle, Darin Slater (aka Slate Rock), who we lost to colon cancer over a year ago. Seeing the love, support, and turnout for this event was a reminder of why community mattersâ€”and why his legacy continues to inspire.

Saturday, March 15, started early, but the energy at the Slate Rocks 5K was unmatched. Friends, family, and the Westwood High Class of â€˜89 came out strong. Commissioner Arnold Gaines was in the crowd. And at the heart of it all? Slateâ€™s Angelsâ€”Iman, Tori, Riley, and Reaganâ€” who put this event together to honor their father and raise awareness for colon cancer.

For me, this run was personal. My uncle Slate Rock wasnâ€™t just my uncleâ€”he was a pillar of the community, a mentor, and one of the biggest reasons Sunland News even exists. He taught me early on that community isnâ€™t just something you live inâ€”itâ€™s something you build. And this event? It was a perfect reflection of that.

ğŸ’™Â March is Colon Cancer Awareness Month, but taking care of your health isnâ€™t just a one-month thing. Iâ€™m grateful we were able to share resources and bring attention to something so important. And I canâ€™t wait to see this 5K grow into something even bigger in the years to come.

ğŸ™ A massive thank you to everyone who showed up, supported, and donated. You made this event special.

Jaâ€™Min Devon

ğŸ‹ The Main Squeeze: Fort Pierce Moves Closer to Paid Parking at Three City Parks

Catch Up: Fort Pierce is moving forward with a paid parking plan for Jetty Park, Jaycee Park, and South Causeway Park to help cover park maintenance costs. Originally, the city planned to keep parking free for locals, but a federal grant requirement may force them to charge everyone.

Whatâ€™s happening: City commissioners are finalizing a contract with PCI Municipal Services to install paid parking kiosks at the three parks. The plan would:

  • Charge $3 per hour, $20 per day, or $60 annually

  • Generate an estimated $900,000 per year, with $585,000 going to the city

  • Allow payment via kiosks or mobile app for added convenience

The city currently spends $303,000 annually on park maintenance, but officials say thatâ€™s not enough to keep up with repairs. Commissioner Michael Broderick put it bluntly:

ğŸ’¬Â â€œOur general fund cannot continue to underwrite persons outside of our community using our assets for free.â€

Why it matters:

  • ğŸš§Â Park upkeep is expensive â€“ Without a dedicated revenue stream, city officials say parks are deteriorating, and upgrades are needed.

  • ğŸ–ï¸ The grant issue complicates things â€“ The city originally promised free parking for locals, but a federal beach nourishment grant tied to Jetty Park requires equal access for all visitors.

  • ğŸš—Â Businesses want more turnover â€“ Limited parking on South Hutchinson Island means some visitors park all day, leaving no room for others. Paid parking could help with turnover.

Whatâ€™s next: The commission hasnâ€™t officially voted on the plan yet, but a majority supports moving forward with paid parking and an annual pass option. The final contract will be brought back for a vote soon.

ğŸ’­Â What do you think? Should Fort Pierce move forward with paid parking, or should locals get a free pass?Â Drop your thoughts here!

ğŸŠ The Press Round: Fee Hike!

ğŸ¡Â Fellsmereâ€™s Population Set to Grow with 332 New Homes

The Marian Estates development will bring 150 townhomes and 182 single-family homes to Fellsmere, starting at $250K and $300K, respectively. While some welcome the growth, others worry about rising taxes and the loss of the cityâ€™s small-town feel.

ğŸ‘‰ Read More

ğŸ—‘ï¸ St. Lucie County Tipping Fee Hike Could Raise Trash Collection Costs

The St. Lucie County Landfill has increased its tipping fees, meaning garbage collection costs will likely rise for Port St. Lucie residents unless the city finds an alternative. County officials say the rate hikes are necessary to keep the landfill financially sustainable.

ğŸ‘‰ Read more

ğŸš†Â Martin County Rejects Quiet Zones for Train Horns

Martin County commissioners voted unanimously against implementing quiet zones, citing safety concerns after three rail-related deaths in the past decade. Officials say additional studies and safety measures would be needed before reconsidering.

ğŸ‘‰ Read more

ğŸ’° Salary Status: City Goes Back and Forth

TL;DR: After weeks of back-and-forth, Fort Pierceâ€™s pick for city manager, Richard Chess, has agreed to a 7.5% pay cut, now proposing a $200,000 starting salary with a potential 5% raise after six months. After not being okay with his intial asking price, commissioners are now split on whether this signals commitment or if Chess sees Fort Pierce as a stepping stone.

Whatâ€™s happening:

  • Chess originally asked for $258,000, later dropping to $235,000â€”both figures exceeding the cityâ€™s advertised range.

  • In response to commission pushback, heâ€™s now offering to start at $200,000, with a possible $10,000 raise after a six-month review.

  • For context: Chess currently makes $215,000 in Broward County, meaning this would be a pay cut.

ğŸ’¬Â Commissioner Michael Broderick:Â â€œWhy is he willing to go from $258,000 to $200,000 in a few conversations? Is this just a stepping stone?â€

Not everyone is concerned. Commissioner Curtis Johnson Jr. sees this as a positive move:

ğŸ’¬Â â€œIt doesnâ€™t trouble meâ€¦ We have someone motivated to move Fort Pierce forward.â€

Why it matters:

ğŸ›ï¸ Fort Pierce needs leadership â€“ After former city manager Nick Mimms was fired amid a criminal investigation, the city has been in crisis mode. Commissioner James Taylor put it plainly:

ğŸ’¬Â â€œWe gotta get someone in here.â€

ğŸ’° The salary still raises questions â€“ Some worry about long-term commitment, while others say a motivated candidate willing to take a pay cut shouldnâ€™t be overlooked.

Whatâ€™s next: The final hiring decision is set for the March 17 commission meeting.

ğŸ’­Â What do you think? Should Fort Pierce move forward with Chess at $200K, or keep looking?Â Drop your thoughts here!

item.description: â˜€ï¸ğŸŒ± PLUS: A heartfelt tribute, CafeÌ 772â€™s new location & St. Pattyâ€™s Day plans!
item.dc:creator: Sunland News
item.content:encoded:
Good Afternoon, Sunland

Itâ€™s Tuesday! Andâ€¦ Mistakes happenâ€”Iâ€™m definitely no stranger to them. But Iâ€™m grateful to have built enough trust with everyone here that when I do slip up, itâ€™s not World War Z.

Yesterday was no exceptionâ€”I mistakenly said that theÂ Peacock House Art Foundation art tour was freeâ€¦ and it wasnâ€™t. Apologies if you showed up expecting free entry!

I spoke with Emily (who was a pleasure to talk to) and went ahead and purchased 10 tickets, just in case someone arrived thinking it was free. Plus, all the proceeds go toward art supplies for kids, so I didnâ€™t mind supporting a good cause. They have an interesting program thatâ€™s worth checking out!

While I wish I hadnâ€™t made the oversight, Iâ€™m glad it turned into something positive.

Alrightâ€¦

Jaâ€™Min Devon

ğŸ‹ The Main Squeeze: 50 Years on the Road: A Tribute to My Grandmother, Martha Vickers

TL;DR: Last Friday, I got to witness something specialâ€”my grandmother, Martha Vickers, being honored for 50 years of service as a school bus driver in St. Lucie County. But this isnâ€™t just a story about her. Itâ€™s about dedication, resilience, and what it means to show up every day for something bigger than yourself.

I got a call from my mom, Sherri Brown, last Tuesday asking, â€œWhat are you doing Friday morning around 8 AM?â€

Nothing much, I told her.

â€œWell, you should come to the North Compound. Your grandmother is being honored for driving school buses for St. Lucie County for 50 years.â€

I was there, of courseâ€”camera in hand, heart full.

At 4:00 AM Friday morning, like she has for decades, my grandmother got up for work. But this time, her final stop was different. At her last pickup, Superintendent Jon Prince stepped onto her bus to ride with her to the compound, where family, colleagues, school board members, and commissioners were waiting.

Flowers. Food. Applause. A celebration she absolutely deserved. She isnâ€™t big on surprises, but I could tellâ€”she felt the love. When asked why sheâ€™s still doing it after all these years, her answer was simple:

â€œI do it for the kids.â€

At that moment, standing there with my camera, I realized this wasnâ€™t just about her. It was a reflection of where I come fromâ€”a family built on service, commitment, and sticking it out even when things get tough.

In the room stood:

  • My cousin, Sylvester aka Lil Me, who drove school buses for St. Lucie County for 20+ years

  • My Aunt Mary (my Grandmaâ€™s twin sister), who has been driving for 41 years

  • My cousin, Iman, now a teacher in St. Lucie County

  • My mom, Sherri Brown, a 34-year educator

  • My Uncle Carnell, a St. Lucie County retiredÂ teacher.

And then there were the ones who couldnâ€™t be there but still deserved to be mentioned:

  • My aunt, Mary Slater, a 34-year educator

  • My cousin, Eyvonda, an educator for nearly 20 years

  • My cousin, Shaunett, also an educator for decades

  • My grandfather, James Vickers, who drove school buses for St. Lucie County for 30+ years but is no longer with us

  • My uncle, Darin Slater, who was a pillar of the community, a barber for over 35 years, and the catalyst behind Sunland News

Iâ€™m sure Iâ€™m leaving out a BUNCH of peopleâ€”my family group chat will let me know after they read thisâ€¦ But it really just came into view how important community and home is in my family and I look to keep that going!

And the celebration isnâ€™t over. Tonight (Tuesday), my grandmother will be recognized at the St. Lucie County School Board meetingâ€”something sheâ€™s been an active part of for years. If youâ€™ve got time, come out and celebrate her. Iâ€™ll be there.

50 years speaks for itself. There are few things in life you can do that long without making a decision, early on, to stick it outâ€”no matter what.

So, if youâ€™re reading this and feeling stuck, uninspired, or unsure, just rememberâ€”commitment is its own kind of legacy.

This oneâ€™s for her. ğŸ’›

From humble beginnings in a gas station to now two locations, CafÃ© 772 is proving that good food and community support go a long way. Known for their legendary birria tacos, theyâ€™ve already made their mark on PSL Blvdâ€”and now, theyâ€™ve relocated their Vero Beach spot to Fort Pierce at 3304 Orange Ave.

Their grand opening weekend drew a crowd, showing just how much people love this Treasure Coast favorite. And if you need another reason to stop by, Baldy Eats has already done a review on the new spotâ€”check it out here!

ğŸ‹ The Main Squeeze: St. Lucie County Expands Again with a New K-8 School

Whatâ€™s going on: St. Lucie County is growing fast, and so are its schools. With Legacy High School set to open in Tradition this August, the county is already moving forward with its next big projectâ€”a brand-new K-8 school, set to open in August 2026.

Why it matters: St. Lucie Countyâ€™s population is booming, and with it, the need for more schools. The district has managed to move quickly and stay on budget by using an existing school model, reducing construction and architectural costs.

  • More K-8 schools are planned over the next five years, along with a new high school in the next seven years.

  • The district aims to make St. Lucie a â€œdestination districtâ€â€”a place where families feel confident sending their kids to school.

  • The former city manager, Nick Mimms, was making $202,000 after nine years before he was fired following his arrest for bid tampering and misconduct.

ğŸ‹ The Main Squeeze: The Battle Over the Brightline Station

TL;DR: Stuart and Martin County officials are set to meet Thursday at 1 p.m. in an attempt to resolve their dispute over who should pay for the $60 million Brightline station planned for downtown Stuart. If they canâ€™t reach an agreement, this could head to court.

Whatâ€™s happening: We thought the Brightline situation was settled back in November when Brightline and the county finally struck a deal to bring a station to Stuartâ€”after the city backed out of its original agreement. Now, a lawsuit is imminent, and the whole thing is getting messy.

  • Stuart backed out of a property lease with Brightline in 2024, arguing the company should pay for half of the station costs.

  • Martin County moved forward on its own, securing a deal with Brightline to build the station on county-owned land.

  • Now, the county wants Stuart to provide a letter of support to help secure grant fundingâ€”but city officials are hesitant without guarantees on cost-sharing.

Why it matters: The station could be a game-changer for transportation and development in Stuart, but it comes down to who foots the bill. The city says the countyâ€™s deal doesnâ€™t match what was originally agreed upon, while the county argues Stuartâ€™s own growth plan supports a downtown train station.

Whatâ€™s next: If a deal isnâ€™t reached at Thursdayâ€™s meeting, a lawsuit could be next. Officials on both sides say they hope to avoid that outcome, but with millions at stake, neither seems willing to budgeâ€”yet.

ğŸ‹ The Main Squeeze
ğŸ† The Pittman Boys: More Than Just Athletesâ€”Theyâ€™re Building a Brand

TL;DR: Four brothers. One brand. A vision beyond football.
